title: Thunderclap Headache Evaluation
icd10: I67.6 (Nonpyogenic thrombosis of intracranial venous system — cerebral venous thrombosis)
E23.6 (Other disorders of pituitary gland — pituitary apoplexy)
scope: ** Emergency evaluation of thunderclap headache (TCH) in adults, defined as a severe headache reaching peak intensity within 60 seconds of onset. Covers the systematic diagnostic algorithm to identify or exclude life-threatening secondary causes: subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT), reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS), cervical artery dissection, pituitary apoplexy, hypertensive emergency, meningitis, and cerebral infarction. Emphasizes the CT-then-LP algorithm, indications for CTA/MRA/MRV, time-sensitive workup, and disposition. Excludes ongoing management of specific diagnoses once identified (see individual templates: SAH, CVT, RCVS, cervical artery dissection, bacterial meningitis, etc.). This is a diagnostic evaluation template, not a disease management plan.

Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; elevated WBC raises concern for meningitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in SAH, CVT, meningitis; low in spontaneous intracranial hypotension (SIH)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal: 6-20 cm H2O. Elevated: >20 cm H2O (SAH, CVT, meningitis). Low: <6 cm H2O (SIH — different mechanism)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Distinguish SAH from traumatic tap: SAH = RBC count does NOT clear significantly between tube 1 and tube 4
Lumbar Puncture.target: SAH: RBCs in tube 4 ≥ tube 1 (no clearing). Traumatic tap: tube 4 << tube 1 (clearing >25%)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Most reliable CSF test for SAH; develops >6h post-bleed from RBC breakdown (bilirubin); spectrophotometry more sensitive than visual inspection
Lumbar Puncture.target: Present = SAH (sensitivity >95% at 12h-2 weeks). Absent at >12h from onset = essentially excludes SAH
Normal 15-45 mg/dL; elevated in SAH and infection

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low CSF:serum glucose ratio (<0.4) suggests bacterial meningitis; normal in SAH
Exclude bacterial meningitis (meningeal signs overlap with SAH)
Neutrophilic pleocytosis (bacterial meningitis); lymphocytic (viral/fungal); mild pleocytosis in SAH (reactive)
Lumbar Puncture.target: SAH: mild pleocytosis (reactive). Meningitis: significant pleocytosis

Essential/First-line.timing: IMMEDIATE — door-to-CT target <25 min. This is the FIRST test for ALL thunderclap headaches. Sensitivity for SAH: ~98-100% within 6h of onset; ~93% at 12h; ~85% at 24h; declines significantly after 3-5 days
Essential/First-line.target: Hyperdense blood in basal cisterns, Sylvian fissure, interhemispheric fissure (SAH); parenchymal hemorrhage; hydrocephalus; mass (pituitary apoplexy); hypodensity (infarct)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None significant — no reason to delay

Essential/First-line.timing: Obtain simultaneously with or immediately after non-contrast CT. Essential to identify: aneurysm (SAH), segmental vasoconstriction (RCVS), dissection (vertebral or carotid), venous thrombosis (if CT venogram protocol included)
Essential/First-line.target: Aneurysm (location, size, morphology); "string of beads" vasoconstriction (RCVS); intimal flap or pseudoaneurysm (dissection); vessel occlusion
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate if time allows; benefit usually outweighs risk in emergency); renal impairment (relative — do not delay for Cr in acute thunderclap)

Essential/First-line.target: Deep T-wave inversions ("cerebral T waves"), ST changes, QT prolongation (SAH); arrhythmia; hypertensive emergency findings

Extended.timing: Within 24h if CT negative and diagnosis uncertain. FLAIR detects subacute blood (SAH >12h); DWI detects ischemia (infarct, vasospasm); T1 with contrast for pituitary mass; SWI/GRE for microhemorrhages
Extended.target: FLAIR hyperintensity in sulci (subacute SAH); DWI restriction (stroke); pituitary mass with hemorrhage; cortical/convexity SAH (RCVS)
Extended.contraindications: Pacemaker/ICD (conditional devices may be scanned); hemodynamic instability; agitation (sedation may be needed)

Extended.timing: With MRI; alternative to CTA if contrast contraindicated or for follow-up
Extended.target: Aneurysm; segmental vasoconstriction (RCVS — may be normal early in course); dissection

Extended.timing: If CVT suspected (headache + risk factors: OCP use, pregnancy/postpartum, thrombophilia, dehydration); or CT venogram unavailable
Extended.target: Absent flow signal in dural sinuses/cortical veins (thrombosis)

Extended.timing: Obtained with CTA using delayed-phase protocol; preferred in ED for speed if CVT suspected
Extended.target: Filling defect in dural sinus; "empty delta sign" (superior sagittal sinus thrombosis)

Extended.timing: GOLD STANDARD for aneurysm detection if CTA negative but clinical suspicion remains high; also detects RCVS vasoconstriction (may require repeat at 2-3 weeks if initially normal); diagnoses vasculitis
Extended.target: Aneurysm missed by CTA; segmental vasoconstriction (RCVS); vasculitis (irregular vessel narrowing); dissection
Extended.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal impairment; coagulopathy (correct first); hemodynamic instability

Extended.timing: 7-14 days if initial DSA negative and non-perimesencephalic SAH pattern; also repeat at 2-4 weeks for suspected RCVS (vasoconstriction may develop delayed)
Extended.target: Previously missed aneurysm; interval development of vasoconstriction

Extended.timing: If SAH confirmed — begin daily from post-bleed day 3 through day 14 (vasospasm window); also detects elevated flow velocities in RCVS
Extended.target: MCA mean velocity >120 cm/s concerning; >200 cm/s severe vasospasm; Lindegaard ratio >3

Extended.timing: If pituitary apoplexy suspected (headache + visual field cut + ophthalmoplegia + known pituitary adenoma)
Extended.target: Hemorrhagic or necrotic pituitary mass; sellar expansion; optic chiasm compression

Extended.timing: On admission if SAH or meningitis; neurogenic pulmonary edema in SAH
Extended.target: Neurogenic pulmonary edema; aspiration; widened mediastinum (aortic dissection with headache)

Extended.timing: If SAH confirmed — neurogenic stunned myocardium (20-30%); if embolic cause suspected
Extended.target: Takotsubo; regional wall motion abnormalities; valvular vegetation; PFO

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology / Vascular neurology — ALL thunderclap headaches; diagnostic guidance; RCVS management; CVT management; dissection
Neurosurgery — SAH confirmed or suspected; aneurysm securing; EVD for hydrocephalus; pituitary apoplexy (transsphenoidal approach)
Interventional neuroradiology / Neuroendovascular — aneurysm coiling; intra-arterial vasospasm treatment; thrombectomy for CVT (refractory); stenting for dissection
Neurocritical care / Neurointensivist — SAH ICU management; deteriorating patient; vasospasm monitoring
Ophthalmology — pituitary apoplexy (visual field assessment); papilledema evaluation; Terson syndrome (vitreous hemorrhage in SAH)
Endocrinology — pituitary apoplexy hormone replacement; long-term pituitary monitoring
Hematology — CVT with thrombophilia; coagulopathy management
Infectious disease — meningitis confirmed or atypical CSF findings
Headache specialist / Neurology outpatient — negative workup; primary thunderclap headache; migraine variant; follow-up for recurrence
Social work / Case management — family support; disposition planning

Patient Instructions.item: Thunderclap headache is a neurological emergency — every episode requires evaluation until a cause is identified or excluded
Call 911 immediately if: sudden severe headache ("worst headache of life"), loss of consciousness, seizure, new weakness, vision changes, fever with stiff neck
Do NOT take aspirin, ibuprofen, or blood thinners before evaluation is complete (may worsen bleeding if SAH)
Avoid triggers: cocaine, amphetamines, triptans, heavy exertion, Valsalva until diagnosis is confirmed
If discharged after negative workup: return immediately if headache recurs with same severity, if new symptoms develop (weakness, vision changes, confusion), or if fever develops
Report any recurrent thunderclap headaches over days-to-weeks to the treating team immediately — recurrence indicates RCVS and requires follow-up imaging even if initial workup is negative
Follow up with neurology within 1-2 weeks after discharge; return sooner if symptoms recur
First-degree relatives of SAH patients: undergo aneurysm screening if 2 or more family members are affected

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Stop all cocaine and amphetamine use immediately (strongly associated with SAH, RCVS, and dissection)
Stop smoking (strongest modifiable risk factor for aneurysm formation)
Maintain blood pressure control (<130/80 mmHg long-term)
Avoid vasoconstrictor medications (triptans, ergotamines, decongestants) until RCVS excluded
Limit alcohol intake (heavy drinking increases SAH risk)
Maintain adequate hydration (dehydration may contribute to CVT risk)
Discontinue oral contraceptives if CVT diagnosed; use non-estrogen alternatives (oral contraceptives increase CVT risk)
Avoid extreme exertion or Valsalva maneuvers during the acute evaluation period

differential.features: Sudden severe headache; loss of consciousness in 50%; meningismus; may have focal deficits; up to 25% present with sentinel headache days before rupture
differential.tests: CT head (blood in basal cisterns); LP (xanthochromia, non-clearing RBCs); CTA (aneurysm)

differential.features: Recurrent thunderclap headaches over 1-3 weeks; triggered by exertion, Valsalva, sexual activity, showering, emotional stress; vasoconstrictor exposure history; may have convexity SAH; no aneurysm
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (multifocal segmental narrowing — may be normal in first week); MRI (convexity SAH, PRES overlap, stroke); resolves on follow-up imaging at 12 weeks

differential.features: Headache (may be thunderclap or progressive); seizures; focal deficits; risk factors: OCP, pregnancy/postpartum, thrombophilia, dehydration; may have hemorrhagic venous infarct
differential.tests: MRV or CTV (absent flow in dural sinuses); CT may show "cord sign" (hyperdense sinus); D-dimer elevated

differential.features: Headache/neck pain (ipsilateral); Horner syndrome (carotid); may have stroke; history of minor trauma, chiropractic manipulation, or connective tissue disorder
differential.tests: CTA neck (intimal flap, pseudoaneurysm, string sign); MRI neck (crescent sign — intramural hematoma on fat-sat T1)

differential.features: Sudden headache + visual field defect (bitemporal hemianopia) + ophthalmoplegia (CN III, IV, VI); known pituitary adenoma (often undiagnosed); may have signs of acute adrenal crisis (hypotension, hyponatremia)
differential.tests: MRI sella (hemorrhagic/necrotic pituitary mass with sellar expansion); hormone panel (cortisol, TSH, prolactin); visual field testing

differential.features: Severely elevated BP (>180/120) with headache and end-organ damage (encephalopathy, renal failure, retinal hemorrhages); no blood on CT; may overlap with PRES
differential.tests: CT (no blood; may show PRES features); BP measurement; end-organ evaluation; MRI (posterior white matter edema in PRES)

differential.features: Fever + headache + nuchal rigidity + altered mental status (classic triad in ~50%); may have rash (meningococcemia); progresses rapidly
differential.tests: LP (neutrophilic pleocytosis, low glucose, high protein, positive gram stain/culture); blood cultures; procalcitonin elevated; CT typically normal

differential.features: Focal deficits with headache; parenchymal hematoma on CT with minimal subarachnoid blood; hypertensive basal ganglia/thalamic location
differential.tests: CT (parenchymal hemorrhage, not cisternal pattern); CTA (no aneurysm unless hemorrhage extends into subarachnoid space)

differential.features: Headache, seizures, visual disturbance, altered mental status; hypertension; often overlaps with RCVS or eclampsia
differential.tests: MRI (posterior white matter vasogenic edema on FLAIR/T2); CT may be normal early; usually reversible with BP control

differential.features: Sudden onset focal deficits; headache present in 25% of strokes; basilar artery occlusion may present with thunderclap headache and rapid deterioration
differential.tests: CT (early signs of infarct; may be normal within 6h); CTA (large vessel occlusion); MRI DWI (acute restricted diffusion)

differential.features: Diagnosis of EXCLUSION after complete negative workup; mimics SAH presentation; may recur; some may represent undiagnosed RCVS
differential.tests: Normal CT, LP, CTA, MRI/MRA; clinical follow-up

differential.features: Orthostatic headache (worse upright, better supine); may present acutely with thunderclap; may have subdural hygromas
differential.tests: MRI (diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement, brain sagging); LP (low opening pressure <6 cm H2O); CT myelography for leak localization

differential.features: Positional thunderclap headache with transient obstruction of foramen of Monro; may cause acute hydrocephalus; rare but dangerous
differential.tests: CT/MRI (hyperdense/enhancing cyst at foramen of Monro; acute hydrocephalus if obstructing)

evidence.recommendation: CT head sensitivity ~98-100% within 6h for SAH
evidence.source: [Perry et al. (BMJ 2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21768192/) — Prospective cohort; 3132 patients; sensitivity 100% (95% CI 97-100%) for CT within 6h

evidence.recommendation: LP mandatory if CT negative but clinical suspicion for SAH persists
Xanthochromia by spectrophotometry is gold standard CSF test for SAH
evidence.source: [Dubosh NM, Bellolio MF, Rabinstein AA, Edlow JA (Stroke 2016)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26797666/); sensitivity >95% at 12h-2 weeks

[White PM et al. (Radiology 2001)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11376263/) — Prospective blinded comparison of CTA and MRA for intracranial aneurysm detection; [White PM et al. (Radiology 2000)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11058629/) — Systematic review of noninvasive imaging for intracranial aneurysms

evidence.recommendation: Anticoagulation for CVT even with hemorrhagic infarct
evidence.source: [ESO Guidelines (Ferro et al. Eur J Neurol 2017)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28833980/); [AHA/ASA CVT Guidelines (Saposnik et al. Stroke 2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21293023/)

evidence.recommendation: Nimodipine 60 mg PO q4h x 21 days for SAH vasospasm prevention
RCVS: calcium channel blockers (nimodipine/verapamil) for headache and vasoconstriction
RCVS: vasoconstriction resolves within 12 weeks — follow-up imaging to confirm
Cervical artery dissection: antiplatelet vs anticoagulation equivalent
Pituitary apoplexy: emergent corticosteroid replacement is life-saving
evidence.source: [UK Pituitary Apoplexy Guidelines (Rajasekaran et al. Clin Endocrinol 2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21044119/)

evidence.recommendation: D-dimer sensitivity ~97% for CVT; negative D-dimer has high NPV
Ottawa SAH Rule: 100% sensitivity for ruling out SAH in ED (validated clinical decision rule)
Recurrent thunderclap headaches over days suggest RCVS over SAH
Primary thunderclap headache is a diagnosis of exclusion only
SBP <160 until aneurysm secured in SAH

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ED and ICU. q1h on floor. SAH: SBP <160 until aneurysm secured. Hypertensive emergency: reduce MAP 20-25% in first hour
monitoring.action: Titrate antihypertensives; arterial line if labile

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 12h; then q2h x 24h; then q4h. Document GCS, pupillary response, motor exam, speech
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT repeat CT; reassess diagnosis; escalate care
If worsening or new thunderclap recurrence: repeat imaging; RCVS likely if recurrent
If febrile: infection workup (blood cultures, UA, CXR); LP if not yet performed; antibiotics if meningitis suspected

monitoring.frequency: q8h (q6h if SAH confirmed — hyponatremia common)
monitoring.action: If <135: differentiate CSW vs SIADH (if SAH); fluid/salt management

monitoring.frequency: Troponin q8h x 24h; then daily if SAH

monitoring.item: aPTT (if on heparin for CVT or dissection)
monitoring.action: Adjust heparin dose; assess for bleeding

monitoring.frequency: Repeat if neurologic change; at 24h if SAH; post-LP if concern for herniation
monitoring.action: New hemorrhage or infarct: escalate to appropriate pathway
If velocities rising: CTA/CTP; induced hypertension if symptomatic

monitoring.frequency: At diagnosis; repeat at 48-72h; long-term outpatient monitoring
At presentation; daily if visual deficits present

disposition.criteria: Complete negative evaluation: normal CT head, normal CTA head/neck, normal LP (performed ≥6h from onset with no xanthochromia, no excess RBCs, normal opening pressure). Stable neurologic exam. Patient understands return precautions. Neurology follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks. Obtain outpatient MRI/MRA if not performed in ED

Inconclusive workup (LP pending, CTA pending, awaiting MRI); persistent severe headache requiring IV analgesia; recurrent thunderclap headaches (RCVS likely); new neurologic deficit; abnormal labs requiring monitoring

Confirmed SAH (all cases — minimum 14-21 days ICU monitoring); CVT with hemorrhagic infarct or declining GCS; pituitary apoplexy with hemodynamic instability; large territorial stroke from dissection or RCVS; any thunderclap headache patient with GCS ≤12 or declining exam
SAH confirmed and no neurosurgery or interventional neuroradiology available on-site — TRANSFER IMMEDIATELY; suspected CVT or dissection requiring endovascular intervention not available locally
Neurology within 1-2 weeks; outpatient MRI/MRA if not done; repeat CTA/MRA at 4-6 weeks if RCVS suspected (vasoconstriction may develop delayed); aneurysm screening for family members if SAH
